messages.content: I really wanted Refracted Beam for my Endless run a couple days ago. Alas, all I found was one Poly Beam.
even in endless Refracted Beam just seems bad, even with good strength
Once you have a core strategy, you can then just decide to upgrade Refracted Beam over and over and over again.
Guardian has better upgrades tbh
an extra 1 instance of strength dump is pretty bad to spend a whole campfire on
Searing Blow is pretty bad, but not *that* bad
I was on floor, like, 200. Everything else was upgraded, and the shovel was giving me Circlets. I wanted the Refracted Beam so I could upgrade something again.
Ig in that context sure, but outside of endless I'd say it is pretty useless

Very similar to pummel, but I think this is a better card by a significant margin. You always have access to red key break in downfall for the +1 strength, and 12 damage for 1 energy is a very good rate for early act 1, especially without even having to spend an upgrade. It doesn't exhaust, letting you play it throughout an entire fight where you are gaining strength, and get a huge payoff later on (pummel can do this, but you have to opt not to play it the first and potentially second time through the deck). Guardian can socket it's version of flex into other cards, which makes it much easier to include in your deck, and far less risky to draw. The random damage isn't that big of a drawback if you play this first in your sequencing, then adjust your later attacks based on the results, and it really only matters in a few aoe fights. It's a really solid early burst damage card that scales well throughout the run, and can be a real part of your plan to eventually beat late game bosses if you have a strength gain engine like construction form or ruby/onyx in the same card.

Sword boomerang but its uncommon and on a character it has much less synergy with. Its terribly medicore. Guardian has several more good attacking cards like floating orbs, walker claw, multibeam, Prismatic Spray and twin slam that can abuse strength scaling reliably while still being operational without strength.
I feel like I agree with Kiku more
Poly Beam is literally <Pummel>, but with exhaust removed and random targeting

Whether you want to compare poly beam to sword boomerang or pummel (both are reasonable, but the numbers are identical to pummel), the key difference for me is that you are playing in downfall mode, and have access to ruby heart blessing (red key break). Being able to have poly beam deal 12 damage for 1 energy without any upgrade needed early in act 1 is incredibly useful, even better if your starting gem was ruby. That's plenty of damage for gremlin nob, lagavulin, and the short hallway fights. It's much better than strike, even very early in the run, since you have +1 strength on demand if you want it. You don't have to go crazy with strength scaling to make it good, the baseline is already solid, and it just gets better and better as you do scale up with ruby/onyx, vajra, girya, akabeko, or construction form.

One is a power, one is a starter that you can't get multiple of so it's tough to say, and the other three are situational at horrible at worst. Prismatic spray is a complete dead draw when you get it until campfires, and not only is it a dead draw. You also need to have multiple bad draws to make it even work. Walker Claw is 2 cost deal 5 damage 3(4) times. That is worse damage per cost than poly beam (most 2 costs are better because the less flexibility of having to spend 2 energy, especially without an energy relic) and worse scaling. Walker claw is just a worse poly beam. Multibeam is the only fair comparison you've made that I could even see a case for. If you ultimately need the aoe then sure.
I think comparing starters to normally obtainable cards is a little weird. The characters are balanced around that starter card, whereas usually a character isn't balanced around a normal card.
and comparing it to a power is just weird.

Walker claw barely outdamages 2 strikes without strengh and the upgrade is meh. It doesn't scale that well with strength compared to other guardian options. I think walker claw is actually pretty horrible tbh.

2 strikes: 12(18) damage
Walker Claw (without strength): 15(20) damage.
Lets compare that to other character's 2 cost common/uncommon big damage attacks.
<overheat> <Carnage> <sword of night> <Predator> <streamline>

I am sometimes looking at **Poly Beam**, and I ask myself "Does this card need a rework?", as while it looks balanced, it kinda solves the issue of getting the most out of your **Strength** by itself, which makes people undervalue other **Strength** multipliers that Guardian has access to.
I don't really see this as this card being too strong as more as other cards being too weak in comparison
But orb slam being changed definitely hits one of the bigger ones
Yeah, I want to add a common card that hits twice, as soon as we get some card space.

the difference between walker claw and poly beam is the context you pick both cards. Walker claw is a good act one damage pick; the fact that it stays relevant later in the game is just a bonus. Poly beam is a card you take in a deck thats already has strength scaling. Prismatic spray is one of guardians best attacks once you get gems in it though; its worth dealing with having a curse temporarily. Orb slam is a power that makes attacks for you; I figured it was close enough (often you can have a deck with strength that only uses orb slams and its more then enough to win)

Walkerclaw is may be underwhelming compared to other cards similar to it; but in the context its placed in (a common attack on guardian) it does fine. On the flip side; polybeam would be a pretty crazy card if ironclad or champ got it. But for guardian I think its just okay; you have it available as a attack that works in a specific kind of deck but its unreliability makes its hard to justify taking frequently.

I think the difference in our thought process is that you guys are looking at how this card does when its at its best. But what i'm seeing is an attack I just skip most of the time. Because its hard to be in a position where I want to go out of my way to take this when the more consistent and flexible choices do more then enough already.
(stays relevant) barely better than 2 strike+ stapled together
It's odd cause I'd much rather draft roll though than walker claw and poly beam than walker claw

its not meant to be an outstanding card; just a usable damage common. I bring it up because it has a decent likely hood to already be in a deck that wants poly beam. Sure poly beam scales better; but they both will get the job done and you may not want even more attacks
I was thinking more on the energy economy side of things
2 energy in act 1 is a tall ask sure with some pots or an early ruby it makes the job easier but I'd rather have a reliable 1 cost
well ya energy wise 2 cost isnt great; but guardian is pretty comfortable sticking with 3 energy for the whole run if you need too; status lets you get away with a lot.

As said before **Poly Beam**'s main weakness are AoE fights, which are the main thing that you build around for act 2, which leaves **Poly Beam** as a late game pick.

because its common card, you see it early game in most runs; you don't see poly beam before you first elite most of the time. I've taken empty prismatic spray into the act 1 boss before; its not so bad guardians able to face tank its way through bad times thanks to defense mode giving you a lot more effective hit points
If you have good Potions you can carry a dead card or two for few floors.

like I talked about walker claw being decent because it hits 3 times. Prismatic spray is hits 3 times while having triple gem effects; it puts pretty much all of your other attacks to shame. also I take prismatic spray/shield when I already have a gem in my deck; I don't think its that great when you are starting with zero gems

For extremely low damage

How good **Prismatic Spray** heavily depends on the amount of Gems you have in your deck when you are able to pick it, but it also means that it is pretty hard to evaluate it in a vacuum.

its not low damage though; you can put damage boosting gems in it; just one ruby and it gets to use its value 3 times. Its doing way more damage then your other attacks without set up and if you have set up it benefits from it more then most cards do

its fine to just put gems in there slowly too; like you can just put 2 inside (you start with one, take prismatic card and another gem after) and then go for your third gem when its convenient. Also ya this is an act 2 kind of card; same with the block one.

Without dying and it can be rough especially if you take this card before an elite
I get the fact it's the best value multihit cause of gem abuse but it's just really really hard to justify
Over alot of cards that could just scale better with gems
Adding gems to your attacks/0 costs/skills gives you more value cause your adding an additional effect to a card that already does something
Is it to say that it's worthless no it gives you gem slots to fill if you decide to load your deck up with gems or get an early pick event
But there are other cards that help that problem easier and just are more reliable/consistent picks
It's basically a risk reward card
Prismatic Spray does also make sack of gems a lot better

this is gonna sound kinda stupid, but just don't die. Guardians strong, theres a lot of raw power behind its cards and you can brute force your way through the spire. Prismatic spray is far from guardians best card; just because its so situational but it has a really strong pay off when you can use it.
for the record I think <prismatic barrier> is much stronger then spray

Alright prismatic barrier is so much better than spray just because there is no other cards that scale extra with dexterity, whereas there are a ton that multihit with strength.

Most times you'll want to put 3 gems in there asap so it isn't actually useless, and that means you won't have good gems in there, so it drops to middle of B tier. And then you also have to account for the fact that you still need to get gems in there.
It's an alright card held back by the fact that you need to actively make your deck worse to use it.

meaning if you grab it in act 1, u need 3 suitable gems before the 2/3rd waypoint before the last campfire on ur path
